clean_content:
Definition / general

* A subset of oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas that are not associated with high risk human papillomaviruses (HPV)

Essential features

* Squamous cell carcinoma involving the oropharynx* Oropharynx includes the soft palate, uvula, palatine tonsils, posterior third (base) of the tongue and posterior wall of the pharynx* Associated with smoking and alcohol* Not associated with HPV* Resembles squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and its morphologic variants observed in other head and neck mucosal sites; can show surface dysplasia, keratinization and desmoplasia

Terminology

* Keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma

ICD coding

* ICD-0: [8086/3](https://seer.cancer.gov/archive/icd-o-3/errata.sitetype.20180117.pdf) - squamous cell carcinoma, HPV negative* ICD-10: [C10](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C00-C14/C10-/C10) - malignant neoplasm of oropharynx

Epidemiology

* Age: mean 61 years (standard deviation 10.49) ([Cancer 2019;125:761](30521092))* M:F = 3.2:1 ([Cancer 2019;125:761](30521092))* Higher incidence in Indian subcontinent, French Polynesia, New Caledonia and Papua New Guinea, Eastern Europe, North America, Australia and Brazil

Sites

* Oropharynx
  + Most commonly soft palate+ Arises in the surface mucosa and invades neighboring structures with metastases to draining regional nodes

Pathophysiology

* Invasive lesion is typically preceded by progressively severe dysplasia* Chronic insult with abrogation of DNA repair mechanisms and mutations in tumor suppressor genes, such as gatekeeper p53 ([J Oncol 2011;2011:603740](21772845))

Etiology

* Most commonly chewing or smoking tobacco, heavy alcohol use and poor oral hygiene ([J Natl Cancer Inst 2008;100:407](18334711))* Also reported in association with syphilis, other infections (bacterial, fungal or viral) and Fanconi anemia ([Int J Epidemiol 1994;23:381](8082966), [Sci Rep 2017;7:4036](28642609), [Arch Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg 2003;129:106](12525204))

Diagrams / tables

Contributed by Katherine Hulme, M.B.Ch.B.  

[![Oropharynx (frontal view)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealHulme01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealHulme01.jpg)

Oropharynx (frontal view)

[![Oropharynx (lateral view)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealHulme02_diagram.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealHulme02.jpg)

Oropharynx (lateral view)

Clinical features

* Presents as nonhealing mucosal ulcer identified by patient or clinician and confirmed with nasoendoscopy and biopsy* Difficulty and pain while swallowing* Metastasis to ipsilateral or bilateral neck nodes may rarely be the initial presenting feature

Diagnosis

* Clinical examination with biopsy of primary lesion* Biopsy of primary lesion may require examination under anesthesia of the oropharynx* Cytology of lymph node metastases followed by biopsy of the primary lesion identified on diagnostic CT and PET scan

Radiology description

* Primarily used for staging of nodal drainage sites and distant spread* PET may identify primary lesion in the rare setting of neck nodal disease of unknown origin

Prognostic factors

* Overall survival at 3 years 57% ([N Engl J Med 2010;363:24](20530316))* Prognostic factors
    + Clinical
      - Tobacco use ([N Engl J Med 2010;363:24](20530316))- Overall patient health, comorbidity and lifestyle factors- Women have worse overall survival and cancer specific survival than men ([Expert Rev Anticancer Ther 2020;20:813](32787745))+ Histological
        - Size- Depth of invasion- Perineural invasion ([J Surg Oncol 2015;111:352](25363330), [Head Neck 2019;41:3992](31487105))- Worst pattern of invasion ([Am J Surg Pathol 2005;29:167](15644773))- Completeness of resection- Lymph node involvement- Extranodal extension- [Stage](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitystagingoropharynx.html) as per the AJCC 8th edition chapter 11 oropharynx (p16) and hypopharynx ([AJCC: Cancer Staging Manual [Accessed 12 December 2020]](https://cancerstaging.org/references-tools/deskreferences/Documents/AJCC%20Cancer%20Staging%20Form%20Supplement.pdf))

Case reports

* 49 year old man with a lymphoepithelial carcinoma in the soft palate and uvula ([Head Neck Pathol 2011;5:327](21698444))* 58 year old woman with a spindle cell carcinoma of the palatine tonsil ([Am J Otolaryngol 2008;29:123](18314024))* 65 year old man with a basaloid squamous cell carcinoma of the retromolar trigone ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2011;15:192](22529579))

Treatment

* Surgical resection of the primary along with ipsilateral or bilateral elective neck dissection ([N Engl J Med 2015;373:521](26027881))* Surgical resection can be through transoral robotic surgery (TORS)* Adjuvant radiotherapy and platinum based chemotherapy* Immune check point inhibitors have demonstrated response in 25 - 29% patients ([Future Oncol 2020;16:1235](32490686))

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealclinical1.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3210216/figure/Fig3/)

Preoperative soft palate tumor

Gross description

* Macroscopic appearance varies with the morphologic type* Common conventional squamous cell carcinoma shows an ulceroproliferative mucosal lesion with a firm gray-white infiltrative surface* Verrucous and papillary squamous cell carcinomas demonstrate prominent exophytic, finger-like projections* Spindle cell carcinoma generally presents as a mucosal polypoid lesion

Gross images

Contributed by Ruta Gupta, M.B.B.S., M.D.  

[![Verrucous mucosal lesion](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealGupta01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealGupta01.jpg)

Verrucous mucosal lesion

[![Ulceroproliferative mucosal lesion](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealGupta02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityHPVunrelatedoropharyngealGupta02.jpg)

Ulceroproliferative  
 mucosal lesion

Frozen section description

* Not routinely done* Value with confirming clearance of margins of primary lesion

Microscopic (histologic) description

* [Squamous cell carcinoma, conventional](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html)
  + Most common and typical morphology of conventional keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma at any site+ Large polygonal malignant cells with intercellular bridges+ Cytoplasmic or extracellular eosinophilic keratin+ Dyskeratotic cells and squamous pearls+ Nuclear size, pleomorphism, hyperchromasia and mitoses increase with increasing grade* Other morphological types
    + [Verrucous carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverrucous.html)
      - Pronounced exophytic growth of well differentiated squamous epithelium- Bulbous enlargement of the rete ridges with elephant foot appearance- Broad pushing border- Does not metastasize; good prognosis+ **Carcinoma cuniculatum**
        - Well differentiated exophytic verruciform lesion with broad front of burrowing invasion- Generally involves mucoperiosteal sites; rare in the oropharynx+ [Papillary squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/larynxpapillaryscc.html)
          - Well differentiated keratinocytes forming exophytic organized papillary structures with fibrovascular cores- 70% of tumor must show papillary architecture- Better prognosis than conventional squamous cell carcinoma+ **Acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma** ([Head Neck Pathol 2012;6:438](22850983))
            - Keratinocytes with loss of adhesion molecules appear "falling apart"- May have pseudolumina mimicking glands or vessels but no mucin+ **Adenosquamous carcinoma** ([Head Neck Pathol 2016;10:486](27169400))
              - True glandular and squamous differentiation close but distinct and separate- Poor prognosis with frequent metastases+ [Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityscc.html) ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2011;15:192](22529579))
                - Cells with minimal cytoplasm- Enlarged, angulated, hyperchromatic nuclei- Basement membrane-like matrix- Solid pattern with lobular configuration- May have prominent peripheral palisading- May have comedo type necrosis- May have abrupt change to differentiated component+ **Lymphoepithelial carcinoma (nonnasopharyngeal)** ([Head Neck Pathol 2011;5:327](21698444))
                  - Cohesive tumor nests of nonkeratinising epithelioid cells with prominent intermixed reactive lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate- Present at high stage with metastases+ [Spindle cell / sarcomatoid squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityspindlecellcarcinoma.html) ([Am J Otolaryngol 2008;29:123](18314024))
                    - Most commonly occurs postradiotherapy or as second primary- Mesenchymal in appearance- Atypical plump spindled cells arranged in fascicles or storiform pattern- May have metaplastic or neoplastic cartilage or bone

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Ruta Gupta, M.B.B.S., M.D.
